title: Fears raised 'rearguard action' will KEEP Brexit Britain in EU's Custom Union
text:
The row comes as Malta’s Prime Minister Joseph Muscat has ditched his country’s close ties with the UK and joined hardliners in Brussels in calling for the UK to be punished for Brexit. 
He said the UK should get a “fair” deal but an “inferior” one to being EU members. 
The fears of a split in the cabinet came as it is understood that Brexit Secretary David Davis reportedly told a private meeting with the Legatum Institute thinktank today that “nothing has been ruled out” with the Customs Union. 
A source close to Mr Davis later told the Express that he “just reiterated what has been said publicly many times by him and other ministers - it isn't necessarily a binary choice and we're considering the options.” We may still end up staying in the Customs Union either fully or partly, which would be a disaster Senior Tory source 
He declined to comment on any rift with the Treasury. 
A senior Tory source said: “It looks like we have won the argument over leaving the Single Market but the messages coming out are suggesting we may still end up staying in the Customs Union either fully or partly, which would be a disaster. 
“It seems that there is a split in the Cabinet and Philip Hammond and the Treasury are fighting hard to keep us in the Customs Union.” GETTY Philip Hammond is reportedly leading an effort to keep the UK in the Customs Union 
Previously, Mr Davis and Theresa May have refused to clarify what the Government’s position on the Customs Union is although the Brexit Secretary has suggested there are four options including a Swiss cooperation model which allows it to make free trade deals around the world. 
Senior Remoaners including Lib Dem former Deputy Prime Minister Nick Clegg and Tory former minister Anna Soubry have pressed the Government to stay in the Customs Union as a means of keeping Britain under Brussels rule by the back door. 
Mr Clegg publicly mocked international trade secretary Liam Fox for “not having a job” because he claimed Britain would “have to stay” in the Customs Union. Top 50 influencers on Brexit Fri, December 2, 2016 Play slideshow 1 of 51 
Last night senior Brexit figures made it clear that there can be no compromise on leaving the Customs Union along with the rest of EU control to allow the UK to make free trade deals around the world. 
Senior Tory MEP and Leave Means Leave board member David Campbell Bannerman said:“The customs union forces Britain to put up protective walls of tariffs making food, clothes and shoes more expensive in the UK. These are heavy chains and are not beneficial.” 
Mr Campbell Bannerman, a member of the European Parliament’s trade committee, added: “As Canada's new CETA deal shows - you can have access to 99 per cent of the market outside the customs union and with no fees or free movement.” GETTY Ukip's Mark Reckless called the Custom Union a straightjacket 
Richmond MP Rishi Sunak, a former international businessman and member of the European Research Group, said: "If we stay inside, Brussels will be in charge of our trade policy, and their track record is awful." 
Fareham Tory MP Suella Fernandes said: “As long as Britain is a member of the customs union, we are unable to strike our own trade deals with countries like the USA or India. 
“It is vital that we leave the Customs Union in order take back control over our trade policy to boost growth and jobs in Britain.” 
Ukip called on Mrs May to “clip Mr Hammond’s wings” and described the potential for free trade deals around the world as “one of the key benefits” of Brexit. 
Ukip economic spokesman Mark Reckless said: “If the Treasury get their way and keep us in the straightjacket of the customs union and it's common tariffs we will be unable to do this.” 
Meanwhile, Malta’s Prime Minister, whose economy receives massive support from the UK and UK citizens, added his voice to attempts to threaten Britain for Brexit as his country takes over the rotating EU presidency. 
Mr Muscat said: "We want a fair deal for the United Kingdom, but that fair deal needs to be inferior to membership. 
"It cannot end up better than the current situation." 
Muscat added that the other 27 countries of the EU would first agree their own position, once Britain formally notifies them it wants to leave before the end of March, and that only then they would negotiations start with London over the terms. GETTY Malta's Joseph Muscat ditched close ties with the UK to call for Brexit punishment 
He said he had rarely seen such unity among EU governments as they displayed in the case of negotiations with Britain. 
His comments comes as EU bosses panic over a series of European elections this year including in France , Holland and Germany which see support for anti-EU parties rocketing up from fed-up voters. 
Mr Muscat said there would be only "one contact point" for negotiations - the European Commission, which would from time to time consult with EU governments when a political decision would need to be made. 
Under pressure European Commission President Jean Claude Juncker, also present at the news conference, said the EU needed to show that the departure of Britain did not mean the end of European integration. 
"If are considering the Brexit case as the beginning of the end, we would make a major mistake," he said. Related articles
